Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> On 10/29/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@... 
> <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
>  >
>  > > I can go with "Test-Driven Development", but "Test-Driven Design" 
> sounds
>  > > very dangerous to me.
>  >
>  > The tests don't actually drive, Cedric. I always drive. The difference
>  > is that I write tests to try out my design decisions as I go. Did you
>  > expect it to be any different?
> 
> That's reasonable, Joe, and also how I do it, but I was commenting on this
> quote:
> 
> I think, when doing TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it is to guide
> your design.
> 
> ... which strikes me as questionable.
> 
> I would also point out that the term "Test-Driven Design" strongly seems to
> imply that your tests drive your design. Which is what I was objecting
> against, and also why I much prefer calling it "Test-Driven Development"
> (and I still think that it's something you should do whenever you can but
> you certainly don't need to do it 100% of the time to obtain well-tested
> code).

I /do/ believe that I benefit more from TDD as a design activity than 
TDD as a testing activity. The tests are a pleasant side-effect of being 
able to evaluate my microdesign as I write tests to drive it.

For macrodesign, of course, I use CRC cards as well as talking to 
people. I find that I used to do not enough of that, and I do more of it 
now.

Take care.
